terms.definition: Standard Operating Procedure - a detailed, written instruction document that describes the steps for performing a routine activity or process to ensure consistency and compliance.
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or files over time, ensuring users always access the most current version while maintaining a history of previous versions.
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems.
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a provider and accessed by users over the internet.
A system that stores all organizational documents in a single, unified platform accessible to authorized users from any location.
A defined sequence of tasks, processes, or steps that documents and data follow from creation to completion within an organization.
Information or data that is processed and made available immediately as it occurs, without delay or batch processing.
Statistical Process Control - a method of quality control that uses statistical techniques to monitor and control manufacturing processes.
The systematic approach to ensuring that an organization adheres to regulatory requirements, industry standards, and internal policies through proper documentation and processes.
Groups of people with different functional expertise working together toward a common goal, requiring shared access to documentation and information.
The ability to track and document the history, application, or location of an item or process through recorded identification and audit trails.
A work process that enables multiple team members to contribute, review, and edit documents or projects simultaneously while tracking changes and contributions.
The use of technology to perform tasks or processes with minimal human intervention, often applied to document management and workflow processes.
A systematic process for identifying the underlying causes of problems or defects to prevent their recurrence.
A data-driven methodology for eliminating defects and improving processes by identifying and removing causes of errors in manufacturing and business processes.
